title: Lots of sex and looking at boobs proven to help men live longer, says science
text:
Yes, boobs (Picture: Getty Images) Here it is men… the secret on how to live a long, happy, healthy life. 
Have lots of sex and stare at boobs.
Woman who tortured neighbour by playing Ed Sheeran on repeat jailed Well, that is according to Medical Daily – who claim getting married and having children is also up there.
After looking into the facts, they revealed that the secret to living a longer life does actually come down to a great sex life.
And getting a ‘dad bod’… excellent.

So number one on Medical Daily’s ‘six things that make men live longer’ list; breasts.
Yes, you may hit that 100-years-old milestone if you stare at a woman’s chest, because – basically – it creates a positive mindset.
Tesco fined £129 million after fraud investigation Apparently, staring at cute animals has the same affect (and you’re probably at lot less likely to get shouted at for doing so).
The second thing is ‘have lots of sex’ – because orgasms could add anywhere between three to eight years onto your life expectancy if you have enough of them.
A study actually found that a man’s mortality risk was reduced by as much as 50% when they increased the amount of sex they were having.

It also relieves stress, therefore reducing the likelihood of illness.
Getting married is also on the list. Yes, men with spouses actually tend to live longer than those who don’t.
In fact, according to Medical Daily, the longer a man stays married, the greater his survival advantage is.
So basically, put a ring on it.
Then comes step four… becoming a parent.
Yes, according to the research, the pitter-patter of tiny feet extends the life expectancy of a man.
Police ride on bus to catch law-breaking motorists A study in the Journal of Epidemiology & Community Health found that men and women with at least one child had lower death risks than those who didn’t.
And by the time the parents reached age 60, men had added two years onto their life.
By age 80, men with children had a remaining lifespan of seven years and eight months, compared to seven years for childless men.
Assume responsibility was the fifth point. Basically because a sense of responsibility improves both daily functioning and longevity.
The final point of advice says get a ‘dad bod’. Yes, really.
Apparently men packing a little more weight are less likely to suffer heart attacks and prostate cancer.
They also – according to the study – are more likely to invest their time in their children.
